Genesis: And he tarried It is written in the Sefer Mikhlol, at the end of the section on verb grammar, that the latter mem has a qamaṣ on account of the shalsheleth cantillation, becuase it follows the rule of pausals. And it is masoretically recorded about this that "there are seven cantillation marks of the Thundering and Pausing" [translator's note: meaning, the cantillation mark shalsheleth appears seven times in the Tanakh, namely here, Genesis 24:12, Genesis 39:8, Leviticus 8:23, Isaiah 13:8, Amos 1:2, and Ezra 5:15] . And thus I saw handwritten in some books. But "If he tarries, wait for him" (Habakkuk 2:3) has a pathaḥ on the second mem.
In the mercy of The beth is plosive.
Numbers: Eliżur. It is written as one word, fully spelled with a yod and fully spelled with a vav. The Ramah (Rabbi Meir HaLevi Abulafia) of blessed memory.

Shede’ur. It is written fully spelled, with a yod and fully spelled with a vav, and the entire Torah is like this. All of them are written as one word. The Ramah (Rabbi Meir HaLevi Abulafia) of blessed memory.

Shelumiel: There is no extended vowel sound (kamatz) under the lamed, and it is written as one word, fully spelled with a yod, and the entire Torah is like this. The Ramah (Rabbi Meir HaLevi Abulafia) of blessed memory.
Tsurishaddai: It is written as one word, fully spelled, with both vav and yod, and the entire Torah is like this. The Ramah (Rabbi Meir HaLevi Abulafia) of blessed memory.
